channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: For the first time, climate models show the 1.5°C goal is dead
item.description: Governments have failed to limit global warming. What comes next?

item.title: What Are China’s Nuclear Ambitions?
item.description: Trump’s testing plans revive scrutiny of Beijing’s growing arsenal.

item.title: The Fall of El Fasher Marks Another Dark Turn in Sudan’s Civil War
item.description: Under Rapid Support Forces control, civilians face summary execution, sexual violence, and famine, experts say.

item.title: The art of Australia’s straight-talking diplomacy
item.description: A foreign service known for being informal and egalitarian has worked a treat for Canberra’s envoys. But does it reward boldness?

item.title: AI’s Rapacious Appetite for Electricity Can Accelerate Clean Energy
item.description: Why Big Tech’s energy problem might prove crucial to fighting climate change.

item.title: China places a Hong Kong-sized bet on Western decline
item.description: The territory aims to prove that a non-free society can be a global financial hub

item.title: First, grinning Labubu dolls. Now, a TV show and theme parks
item.description: Pop Mart, maker of the wildly popular toys, wants to be China’s Disney

item.title: How the sheriff of St Louis ended up in jail
item.description: And what it says about Democratic cities in Republican states

item.title: COP30’s Dangerous Omission
item.description: Brazil’s people-centered climate vision risks abandoning the most vulnerable.

item.title: What Does Trump Think Nuclear Testing Is?
item.description: A vague statement opens a range of expensive possibilities.

item.title: How Beijing Views Trump
item.description: A top China scholar and former Biden administration advisor on the Trump-Xi meeting and the future of the U.S.-China relationship.

item.title: Analysing Africa newsletter: Donald Trump is focusing on the wrong atrocities
item.description: If only the president would turn his gaze to Sudan, says John McDermott, our chief Africa correspondent

item.title: Could the Financial Action Task Force Save U.N. Sanctions?
item.description: As a more technical body, the task force might be able to fill the gap left by Security Council paralysis.

item.title: In Hurricane Melissa’s Wake, Trump’s Foreign Aid Cuts Face Critical Moment
item.description: The storm’s devastation is a key test of the United States’ reduced humanitarian response abilities.

item.title: Ireland’s Next President Will Assume the Progressive Mantle
item.description: Anti-war candidate Catherine Connolly’s victory is the country’s latest rebuke to the global right-wing populist wave.

item.title: Ukraine’s New U.S. Ambassador Previews Her Pragmatic Approach to Washington
item.description: “I am Ukrainian, right? I’m not a Democrat or Republican.”

item.title: Uzbekistan to Introduce Visa-Free Entry for US Citizens From January 1
item.description: Meanwhile, Uzbek citizens face one of the highest visa-refusal rates in the United States.

item.title: How Many More Cloud Scares Does Europe Need?
item.description: Three US companies – Amazon, Google, and Microsoft – now control over 60% of the global cloud market, implying major economic and security risks for Europe. Dismantling these monopolies in the European market, and building sovereign digital infrastructure, is not just possible, but essential.

item.title: How Donald Trump can dodge a Supreme Court tariff block
item.description: No matter the ruling, the president has back-up powers

item.title: The Fraught Politics of Corporate Disclosures
item.description: The US Securities and Exchange Commission must recognize that a wide variety of interests look at corporate financial disclosures, and that the effects of such information can be material in a variety of ways. To reject environmental, social, and governance concerns as political is itself an example of politicization.

item.title: An EU-Mercosur trade deal looks close to ratification
item.description: In a hostile world, Europe and Latin America draw closer

item.title: Japan’s New Government Boasts High Approval Ratings
item.description: New Prime Minister Takaichi enjoys far more support than her immediate predecessors in the early stages of their terms.

item.title: India, US Seek to Stabilize Relations By Renewing Defense Pact
item.description: New Delhi’s strategy for now seems to be to manage the relationship with the U.S., which till recently was deemed as vital to counter China.

item.title: India’s Tryst With Strategic Experimentation
item.description: For India, progress has often begun as a gamble. Appetite for experimentation could be its key strategic asset.

item.title: Beyond Fiber-Optic Cables: Securing Seabed Before the Next Crisis
item.description: Communications cables are only part of the story. A far broader array of systems now covers the ocean floor – and must be protected.

item.title: What Chinese Leaders Really Think of Trump
item.description: According to Chinese academics, economists, and retired military officers, the country's leaders are not losing any sleep over Donald Trump's America First agenda. In fact, as they see it, the US president is ushering in a world that Chinese strategists have long been preparing for.

item.title: Malaysia Must Stop Enabling Iran’s Sanctions Evasion
item.description: The waters off Malaysia have been the site of more than 500 illicit ship-to-ship transfers involving Iranian oil since the start of 2025.

item.title: US Tech Firms Are Bound by China’s Rising Techno-Nationalism
item.description: As Beijing feeds growing suspicion of U.S. technology products, an expanded move away from American tech could be incoming.

item.title: US & Central Asia: What Is the C5+1?
item.description: On November 6, 2025, the Central Asian presidents will gather in Washington DC. The summit will be the crowning achievement for a decade-old format.

item.title: Dick Cheney’s Legacy: One of the Worst Strategic Failures in U.S. History
item.description: The former U.S. vice president set out to strengthen the power of the presidency and the country but ultimately undermined both.

item.title: Mongolia’s Defector Dilemma: Navigating the Korea Divide
item.description: Mongolia's bid to remain a neutral bridge between North and South Korea must find a way to balance idealism and pragmatism.

item.title: Adam Smith and the Moral Economy We Have Lost
item.description: Adam Smith favored neither state socialism nor unbridled markets, but something subtler: a moral economy grounded in sympathy and the pursuit of human flourishing. In a world where markets look increasingly unmoored from ethics, we could do worse than to revisit what the "founding father" of economics actually wrote.

item.title: Can the Opposition End the 20 Years of BJP-JD(U) Rule in India’s Bihar?
item.description: Bihar has traditionally seen bipolar election contests. With the entry of the Jan Suraaj party, the contest is triangular this time.

item.title: What Can Europe Offer a Fragmenting World?
item.description: As the rivalry between the United States and China intensifies, many countries are seeking partners they can trust. The European Union could fill that role by offering economic opportunity, a secure investment environment, and legal systems that are predictable and fair.

item.title: Can the Developing World Weather the Next Financial Crisis?
item.description: As asset prices soar and speculative money floods into risky markets, the global financial system is slipping back into perilous territory. When the inevitable correction arrives, the fallout will spread far beyond the United States and Europe, hitting developing economies already weighed down by debt and uncertainty.

item.title: Gaza ceasefire moves forward
item.description:
The peace plan of the US president, Donald Trump, designed…

The post Gaza ceasefire moves forward appeared first on Economist Intelligence Unit.

item.title: Pakistan’s Generals Are Marching Toward Another Disaster
item.description: The military’s approach reflects a familiar pattern: engaging in external aggression to mask internal decay and disarray.

item.title: Through the Tempest: The Philippines’ Defense Posture in Troubled Waters
item.description: Domestic challenges threaten to derail the military's efforts to upgrade its capabilities and reorient itself toward new strategic priorities.

item.title: Indonesia’s Belt and Road Railway to Nowhere
item.description: For a while, it looked as if China had learned its lesson on scaling back investments.

item.title: Making Multipolarity Work
item.description: How America should navigate a new global order.

item.title: Japan Can Keep the Indo-Pacific Open and Free
item.description: With America stepping back, Tokyo should step up.

item.title: With Sanae Takaichi, “Japan is back” is back
item.description: Coalition politics, tax resistance and ambitious defence spending goals will require the new PM to strike a fine balance.

item.title: Philippine, UAE Have Applied for CPTPP Membership, Report Claims
item.description: The 12-nation trade pact is attracting prospective members eager to preserve the current global multilateral trading regime.

item.title: Beyond AUKUS: The maritime strategy Australia needs
item.description: Consolidating maritime departments, and coordination across defence, civil and industry is where the wins will be made.

item.title: The Strategic Costs of U.S. Exchange Program Cuts in Southeast Asia
item.description: Such programs are a cost-effective and proven form of partnership-building. Their loss will undermine U.S. influence in a crucial region of the Indo-Pacific.

item.title: Philippines, Canada Sign Visiting Forces Agreement Amid South China Sea Tensions
item.description: The agreement is the fifth that Manila has signed, after similar deals with the United States, Australia, Japan, and New Zealand.

item.title: Timor-Leste: to join the ASEAN neighbourhood, start with the house next door
item.description: Indonesia could make ASEAN membership meaningful for Timor-Leste by opening up ferries and flights from Kupang.
